What is an AI Operator business model?.query: What is an AI Operator business model?
What is an AI Operator business model?.answer: An AI Operator business model leverages AI agents to automate tasks and enhance customer experiences, optimizing workflows and improving efficiency. It focuses on integrating AI into existing business processes to create new opportunities. The model aims to free human resources for higher-value tasks.

results.title: Introducing Operator
results.content:
Operator⁠(opens in a new window) transforms AI from a passive tool to an active participant in the digital ecosystem. It will streamline tasks for users and bring the benefits of agents to companies that want innovative customer experiences and desire higher rates of conversion. We’re collaborating with companies like DoorDash, Instacart, OpenTable, Priceline, StubHub, Thumbtack, Uber, and others to ensure Operator addresses real-world needs while respecting established norms. In addition to these collaborations, we see a lot of potential to improve the accessibility and efficiency of certain workflows, particularly in public sector applications. To explore these use cases further, we’re working with organizations like the City of Stockton⁠(opens in a new window) to make it easier to [...] How Operator works

Operator is powered by a new model called Computer-Using Agent (CUA). Combining GPT‑4o's vision capabilities with advanced reasoning through reinforcement learning, CUA is trained to interact with graphical user interfaces (GUIs)—the buttons, menus, and text fields people see on a screen.

Operator can “see” (through screenshots) and “interact” (using all the actions a mouse and keyboard allow) with a browser, enabling it to take action on the web without requiring custom API integrations.

If it encounters challenges or makes mistakes, Operator can leverage its reasoning capabilities to self-correct. When it gets stuck and needs assistance, it simply hands control back to the user, ensuring a smooth and collaborative experience. [...] Today we’re releasing Operator⁠(opens in a new window), an agent that can go to the web to perform tasks for you. Using its own browser, it can look at a webpage and interact with it by typing, clicking, and scrolling. It is currently a research preview, meaning it has limitations and will evolve based on user feedback. Operator is one of our first agents, which are AIs capable of doing work for you independently—you give it a task and it will execute it.

results.title: What is an AI agent?
results.content: AI-native enterprises and operating models. These agents are woven throughout the enterprise operating model, instead of being applied to individual workflows or functions. In these cases, a company undergoes an end-to-end AI-first redesign where the interaction layer, processes, organizational structures, and even the business model are reimagined. Organizations experienced changes of this magnitude when they first underwent digital transformations, and the same is likely to happen with AI. [...] Get ahead of the talent, technology, and operating-model implications. As the multiagent approach scales, leaders will need to understand and plan for the business implications. These include rethinking their talent strategy and reskilling programs, adapting their operating models accordingly, and reevaluating their operating and capital expenditures. [...] AI virtual workers. AI virtual workers are agents that function as employees or team members and represent the most potentially disruptive category of agents. These virtual workers could enable companies to sidestep full organizational transformation by allowing AI to operate within the company’s current model, which might help capture value more quickly.

These business models tap into AI’s ability to glean contextual cues from huge volumes of data, simulate outcomes, and become smarter and more efficient with every user, transaction and interaction—enabling companies to monetise high-frequency activity that has been too complex to manage. Because these business models are rooted in broad collaboration across industries, regions and businesses, they will be more dependent on trust and trust solutions—with shared standards and automated, scalable mechanisms [...] By Paul Blase and Matthew Duffey

AI isn’t just improving corporate productivity and efficiency. It’s poised to reshape how value is defined, delivered and captured with its ability to create content, ideas and logic, and solve problems autonomously. The result: new AI-fuelled business models are challenging long-standing business assumptions and further blurring industry boundaries, contributing to massive new value pools and growth opportunities that will emerge over the next decade and beyond. AI-driven CRM platforms analyze customer data to predict preferences and optimize communication. For instance, examples of AI business applications in this area include predictive support tools that efficiently route requests and shorten resolution times, in addition to advanced chatbots that provide 24/7 assistance. Therefore, these systems improve user experience and ease the workload on human operators.

### Recommendations and inventory optimization in retail [...] ### Automated customer support with GenAI

GenAI represents the next evolution of customer assistance. Unlike old, rule-based chatbots, GenAI can understand complex, nuanced human language. Therefore, it is capable of summarizing entire conversations, finding the right answer instantly, and autonomously handling a wider variety of issues. This automated support significantly improves the user experience while maintaining the high quality of interaction human operators expect.

Logistics industry India major pain poin.query: Logistics industry India major pain points 2024 2025
Logistics industry India major pain poin.answer: Major pain points in India's logistics industry include infrastructure bottlenecks, labor shortages, and rising operational costs. Government initiatives aim to address these through infrastructure investment and policy reforms. The sector faces challenges in integrating fragmented systems and managing logistics efficiency.

results.title: Infrastructure Challenges for Logistics in India and ...
results.content:
India is actively addressing these challenges through large-scale infrastructure development initiatives. The government has increased capital allocated to logistics infrastructure projects. It has committed a record 11.11 trillion rupees ($132.85 billion) on infrastructure in the financial year ending March 2025. Through the Logistics Efficiency Enhancement Programme (LEEP), India aims to improve freight transport efficiency with infrastructure technology and process interventions The Bharatmala Pariyojana, a $130 billion highway development program, aims to enhance road connectivity and improve the efficiency of freight movement across the country. Under this program, 35 multi-modal logistics parks (MMLPs) have been developed to provide world-class infrastructure for warehousing, [...] ## Skilled Labour Shortages

While the logistics industry in India is grappling with rising input costs on one hand, including fuel, electricity, and wages, simultaneously, there is also a significant shortage of skilled labour, particularly in advanced roles like warehouse automation and supply chain analytics. Only 4.7% of the 22 million employees in the logistics sector are formally skilled. Additionally, the logistics sector faces a separate 20% deficit in truck drivers, with only 80,000 available compared to the 100,000 needed. The aging logistics workforce is further leaving a gap as experienced professionals retire leaving behind a younger talent who is deterred by the perception of logistics as less appealing and lucrative compared to tech or finance sectors. [...] ## Economic Pressures and Market Dynamics

The warehousing and logistics sector in India faces mounting pressure from rising operational costs, due to inflation and volatile fuel prices. Diesel prices account for up to 60% of logistics costs in India, making freight companies particularly vulnerable to price hikes. Furthermore, intense competition limits the ability of operators to pass on these increased costs to customers, eroding profit margins. Smaller operators, in particular, struggle to stay afloat under such financial strain.

Government’s introduction of the GST has simplified tax structures with the aim to reduce the overall cost of warehousing and transportation.

results.title: Logistics Industry Outlook 2025 - Infosys
results.content:
The logistics market is experiencing strong growth due to a surge in online shopping and growing delivery demands. This expansion brings additional complexity, with companies needing to manage a range of delivery options, inventories, and customer preferences. Successful companies will be those that can efficiently balance these competing priorities while delivering a smooth customer experience.
 Higher transportation costs, labor shortages, and disrupted supply chains are adding pressure to the industry. Rising delivery expectations further raise the bar for companies to perform efficiently and cost-effectively. Implementing advanced technologies and optimizing workforce management can aid companies in navigating these pressures. [...] A key factor driving labor shortages in logistics is an aging workforce. A large share of employees, particularly truck drivers, warehouse staff, and freight handlers, are approaching retirement, and the industry is struggling to attract younger talent. Many logistics roles, such as warehouse pickers and delivery drivers, are physically demanding, offer limited career progression, and lack appeal to new entrants. The combination of long hours, relatively low pay in some segments, and limited work-life balance contributes to high attrition rates. At the same time, the rapid growth of e-commerce has intensified pressure on logistics companies, making it difficult to scale labor capacity in line with surging order volumes. [...] This could be in the form of looking at non-US markets; shifting manufacturing to the US to avoid import tariffs; sourcing from alternate locations and reducing reliance on low-margin products — such as fast-fashion garments, small auto parts, inexpensive electronics — that are affected by tariffs. Nearshoring is booming. FedEx shares fell 8% due to lesser B2B volumes. Demand for warehousing facilities is increasing with brands needing space to stock their products while they come up with contingency plans or shipping from domestic warehouses.

results.content:
+91 7484058164   shashankrai434@gmail.com   Brochure

## 📦 Logistics in India: Key Facts, Growth Trends & Challenges (2025 Overview)

Fresh SSB batches start around the 1st & 15th of every month.

🚀 1. Logistics Performance Index (LPI)

 India ranked 38th out of 139 countries in the 2023 World Bank LPI.
 Steady rise from 54 in 2014 and 44 in 2018.

💰 2. Logistics Costs & GDP Share

 Logistics costs: ~8% of India’s GDP (7.97% in 2023–24).
 Target: Reduce to ~9% or lower by Dec 2025.

📈 3. Market Size & Growth

 2024 estimate: USD 317.26 billion.
 2029 projection: USD 484.43 billion at ~8.8% CAGR.
 Long-term: Could reach ₹120 trillion (~USD 1.2 trillion) by 2035.

🧩 4. Contribution to GDP & Employment

 Contributes 13–14% to GDP.
 Employs 22+ million people, with more jobs expected. [...] ⚠️ Challenges & Weak Points

 Sector remains unorganized and fragmented; formalization expected by 2035.
 Issues: last-mile delays, regulatory bottlenecks, poor remote connectivity.
 Road transport dominates but is costlier than rail/water; modal integration is complex.
 Infrastructure bottlenecks: port congestion, limited inland waterways, lack of intermodal facilities.

 Logistics real estate growing at 25%+ annually (2025).

AI automation opportunities in Indian lo.query: AI automation opportunities in Indian logistics sector
AI automation opportunities in Indian lo.answer: AI and automation are transforming India's logistics sector by optimizing routes and improving efficiency, while creating new high-skilled jobs. Major companies like Amazon are investing heavily in AI-driven logistics to boost operational efficiency and support job growth. The sector is increasingly adopting advanced technologies for smarter, more responsive supply chains.

results.title: AI and Automation: The Next Frontier in Indian Logistics
results.content:
In India, a fixed delivery route is a promise you're likely to break. AI introduces a fluid, intelligent approach to transportation. [...] This is a crucial point. The most effective AI solutions for the Indian market are those built or configured with local realities in mind. Modern AI routing algorithms, for instance, can factor in everything from highway tolls to rural road conditions and monsoon-related disruptions. Similarly, AI for document processing can be trained on India-specific paperwork, making it highly effective in our complex regulatory environment. [...] Ask a Question

In logistics, Artificial Intelligence (AI) is the "brain" – it refers to systems that can learn from data, predict outcomes, and make intelligent decisions (e.g., forecasting demand or optimizing a route). Automation is the "muscle" – it involves using technology to perform repetitive tasks without human intervention (e.g., robots moving goods in a warehouse or software auto-processing invoices). Together, they create a smarter, more efficient supply chain.

results.title: The Job Boom No One Saw Coming - Logistics Insider
results.content:
## THE NEW LOGISTICS WORKFORCE:

Automation in the Indian logistics sector is less about large-scale job elimination and more about a structural shift in how work gets done.

A very good example of this can be our major gateways like Mundra and JNPT, which visibly use AI-enabled planning systems, robotics, and IoT. Automated cranes, smart yards, and sensor-driven container tracking have reduced dependence on manual handling and improved turnaround times, in some cases lifting operational efficiency by 30–40%. [...] The Job Boom No One Saw Coming: Automation Creating New Skills in Indian Logistics

 anticipates that AI will generate a net increase of 78 million jobs by 2030, creating more roles than it displaces.

Welcome to Logistics Insider   Click to listen highlighted text! Welcome to Logistics Insider

, the green transition, and demographic shifts.

92 million jobs are projected to be displaced by these same trends.

This indicates a significant job churn and reiterates that automation is creating new, high-skilled opportunities, rather than eliminating jobs.

## THE NEW LOGISTICS WORKFORCE: [...] Echoing this view, Parvinder Singh, MD, Hans Infomatic, says, “We believe automation is not replacing jobs but transforming the very nature of work in the logistics sector. The real opportunity is not about replacing people but about enabling them to work more effectively alongside technology. When teams have access to intuitive digital tools, automation helps remove everyday bottlenecks, reduces manual effort, and gives professionals the time and space to focus on higher-value responsibilities such as exception handling, customer coordination, and operational planning.”

results.title: Logistics Automation in India: How Top Companies ... - Imbibe Tech
results.content:
### Conclusion: Embracing the Digital Logistics Era

The next phase of growth in India’s logistics sector will be powered by innovation, automation, and integration. Leading businesses are already investing in logistics and supply chain automation platforms to optimize operations, improve customer satisfaction, and future-proof their logistics networks.

From reverse auction platforms to real-time delivery tracking, tools like ItHaul are shaping the new normal in Indian supply chains. With features like descriptive report generation, cloud-based control, multilingual support, and WHO-certified accuracy, ItHaul isn’t just another logistics platform—it’s the smartest logistics partner for India’s future. [...] Logistics in India has traditionally been labor-intensive and fragmented, with heavy reliance on manual processes, paper-based documentation, and decentralized systems. However, in recent years, technological advancements and rising digital adoption have begun reshaping the sector.

With the growth of e-commerce, urbanization, and increased demand for same-day or next-day deliveries, logistics providers and businesses alike are turning to supply chain automation platforms to manage operations efficiently. Platforms like ItHaul by Imbibe Tech have become pivotal in this transformation by offering AI-powered tools, real-time visibility, automated workflows, and reverse bidding capabilities tailored for Indian conditions. [...] ### Accelerating the Journey Toward Smart Logistics

India’s logistics industry is standing at a digital crossroads. With rising competition and customer expectations, there’s no time for manual inefficiencies. Companies that fail to automate risk falling behind.

Platforms like ItHaul by Imbibe Tech are helping bridge the gap between traditional logistics and future-ready operations. By combining reverse bidding, real-time tracking, analytics, flexible printing, digital documentation, and customizable reporting, ItHaul is empowering Indian businesses to compete globally.

If you’re a manufacturer, distributor, or enterprise seeking to reduce logistics costs and enhance operational agility, logistics automation is the way forward—and ItHaul is your best partner.

Amit adds:  “Looking ahead, we're excited to continue being a catalyst for India’s growth, as we democratise access to AI for millions of Indians and quadruple cumulative ecommerce exports enabled to US$80 billion by 2030."

It is becoming a competitor within the global logistics market, with experts predicting continuous growth. The increasing digitalisation and job expansion, operational efficiency is increasing, networks are growing and India is establishing itself as a logistics competitor.

Profitable offers for AI agencies target.answer: Profitable AI offers for logistics companies include AI load-to-vehicle matchers, predictive maintenance agents, and AI-driven supply chain planning systems. These solutions reduce costs, improve efficiency, and enhance operational visibility.

results.title: 5 Powerful AI Agents for Logistics & Supply Chain Businesses
results.content:
# December 16, 2025

# | By

Sreedhar Tatavarthi

# 5 Powerful AI Agents for Logistics & Supply Chain Businesses

In today’s competitive logistics landscape, margins are razor-thin and expectations are sky-high. Whether you run a freight brokerage, a 3PL, or manage your own fleet — the winners are no longer just the ones who move fast. They’re the ones who think smart.

That’s where AI agents come in. We're not talking about abstract AI ideas or dashboards that sit unused. These are practical, buildable agents that can plug into your existing systems and start saving time, money, and mistakes — today.

Here are 5 high-impact AI agents that logistics teams are using to drive real results.

### 1. AI Load-to-Vehicle Matcher [...] ### 1. AI Load-to-Vehicle Matcher

Details:  
Dispatchers often juggle spreadsheets and phone calls to assign loads — leading to suboptimal fill rates, longer routes, and wasted capacity. This AI agent takes your list of shipments and available trucks, then auto-generates load plans that maximize cube/weight fill and minimize empty miles.

Example:  
You’ve got 27 LTL shipments going out of Houston. The agent recommends combining 12 of them into just 3 trucks using dynamic routing logic — cutting 4 hours and 90 miles from your day.

Business Impact:

- Fewer total trips  
- Lower fuel and labor costs  
- Improved OTIF and SLA compliance  
- Higher fleet ROI

### 2. AI Quote-First Agent (Website Embedded) [...] Business Impact:

- Cuts manual data entry  
- Reduces errors in invoice/payment cycles  
- Speeds up processing from hours to minutes  
- Unlocks automation for low-tech partners

### 5. Predictive Maintenance Agent (Audio + Vibration AI)

Details:  
In logistics, breakdowns mean missed SLAs, detention fees, and angry clients. This agent uses sensors to “listen” to forklifts, conveyor belts, reefer units, or trucks — detecting early signs of mechanical issues long before failure.

Example:  
A trailer’s reefer unit starts vibrating abnormally. The agent detects it overnight and flags it for inspection before the cold chain is broken.

Business Impact:

- Fewer unexpected breakdowns  
- Longer equipment life  
- Less downtime = more revenue  
- Increased safety for warehouse/fleet ops

‍

Pricing: A package for a set number of tailored applications (e.g., $399 for 5).

### 19. AI Event Planning & Coordination Assistant Service

The Opportunity: Event planning is a $500+ billion industry built on logistics and communication. AI can automate the repetitive "grunt work" that consumes a planner's time.

Application: Offer an "AI assistant" to professional event planners. The agent can research and contact vendors for quotes, manage RSVPs via email, and send out automated reminders to guests and suppliers.

results.title: How Logistics Operators Harness AI To Boost Efficiency
results.content:
Exhibit 1: Logistics AI use case mapping

Selection of applications (interactive dots — hover to view details)

Source: Oliver Wyman analysis

## Quantifying AI’s cost savings and profit uplift in logistics sectors

Collectively, these six categories enable logistics firms to target cost reductions between 10% and 25% percent across operational pools such as selling, general, and administrative (SG&A), last-mile delivery, sorting, and warehouse management. This translates into aggregate improvements in earnings before income and taxes (EBIT) of 1% to 2% — a notable uplift for an industry operating on average margins of 3% to 5%. [...] Currently, most logistics firms allocate less than 15% of their IT budget and under 0.5% of overall revenue to AI. Quick wins are possible through routine automation, but scaling more advanced analytics and physical automation requires a cohesive, phased business strategy and investments.

## Strategic AI implementation to secure a competitive advantage in logistics

AI is an operational imperative for logistics operations. Early adopters demonstrate that practical deployments can generate swift, substantial efficiency improvements. The greatest returns begin in back-office workflows and visibility enhancements, with expanding potential in warehouses, sorting, and last-mile delivery. [...] 1. Routine automation in business operations. AI automates routine business transaction processing, including managing inbound emails, quoting prices, setting appointments, and tracking shipments. These applications reduce manual workload and errors, achieving 10% to 20% cost savings within three to six months, with investments typically between €500,000 and €1 million.
2. Relational or human interaction support. AI-powered chatbots enhance customer service by managing delivery inquiries, enabling message replays, processing cancellations, and facilitating proactive delivery adjustments. These solutions can handle up to 30% of inquiries end-to-end and cut agent handling time by approximately 50%.

results.title: Top 25 AI Logistics & Supply Chain Startups in 2025 - Omdena
results.content:
### 1. Rippey AI

Rippey AI (formerly RPA Labs) specializes in automating business processes for companies in the supply chain and logistics industries. Their solutions focus on eliminating manual, repetitive tasks by leveraging conversational AI, natural language processing, and machine learning. This helps logistics companies scale without increasing their workforce, streamlining back-office operations such as accounts payable and accounts receivable, and automating tasks like responding to shipping quotes and creating shipments. [...] ### 20. Raft

Raft specializes in providing AI-powered logistics solutions to enhance efficiency and customer service in the logistics industry. Their platform automates various logistics processes, including freight forwarding, customs brokerage, accounts payable reconciliation, and warehouse operations, by leveraging advanced AI technologies like large language models (LLMs) and transformers.

Raft’s AI-driven platform processes over 5 billion data points and labeled logistics documents, which are used to train machine learning models and improve generative AI capabilities. This technology enables the automation of workflows, allowing logistics companies to focus on high-value tasks rather than manual data entry.

Founders and Key Executives: James Coombes (CEO & Co-Founder). [...] ### 7. Greenscreens.ai

Greenscreens.ai specializes in providing dynamic pricing infrastructure for the freight market, focusing on predictive freight pricing and market intelligence. Their solutions empower freight brokers and third-party logistics providers to increase profit margins by offering accurate buy and sell rates. By combining aggregated market data with historical transaction information, Greenscreens.ai delivers short-term predictive pricing tailored to each company’s buying and selling behavior.

results.title: Top 10 AI Logistics Solutions Transforming Supply Chain Efficiency
results.content:
### 3. Improved Customer Experience

 By automating basic customer inquiries, AI-powered systems provide faster, more accurate responses.
 End-to-end visibility in supply chain planning helps logistics companies meet customer demand with fewer disruptions.

The result is a supply chain that’s leaner, faster, and more responsive to change.

## Leveraging AI in Logistics Operations

Leveraging AI strategically requires integrating intelligence at each operational layer—from planning and routing to fulfillment and after-sales support. [...] ### Supply Chain Planning

 By analyzing market trends, AI enables dynamic supply chain planning, supporting just-in-time delivery models and more accurate capacity forecasting.

Modern logistics firms are using these tools to stay ahead of disruptions and maintain continuity in volatile environments.

## Generative AI in Logistics: A New Frontier

Beyond classical machine learning, generative AI is unlocking new opportunities for logistics companies. [...] As logistics companies face increasing pressure to reduce costs, meet customer expectations, and build more resilient supply chains, AI models and machine learning algorithms are emerging as essential tools. These technologies enable predictive demand forecasting, route optimization, intelligent warehouse management, and real-time decision-making.

For logistics managers, the question is no longer whether to adopt AI—but how strategically and at what scale.

            

## Strategic Benefits of AI in Logistics

AI-powered logistics solutions offer measurable, bottom-line impact. By embedding AI systems directly into supply chain operations, logistics firms can unlock gains across planning, execution, and service delivery.

### 1. Cost Reduction and Efficiency Gains

results.title: Top 5 AI startups solving logistics bottlenecks in India - IndiaAI
results.content:
### LogiNext

Founded in 2014 by Dhruvil Sanghvi and Manisha Raisinghani, LogiNext provides AI-enabled solutions for logistics and on-field workforce planning, tracking, and optimisation. The platform allows enterprises to have complete visibility over delivery drivers (be it third party or their own fleet). Through features like auto-order allocation and route optimisation, the platforms efficiently manage drivers to reduce delivery costs, increase customer experiences and help brands navigate through the problem of driver shortage in a better fashion. [...] LogiNext has raised $50 million over three rounds of funding (as of January 2022), and the plan is to build LogiNext into an IPO ready company by focusing relentlessly on customer success, growing revenues and ensuring a great work culture.

### Pickrr

Founded in 2015 by by Rhitiman Majumder, Gaurav Mangla, Ankit Kaushik and Ronak Agrawal. Gurugram-based Pickrr is a SaaS-based logistics startup that helps D2C firms build their business by leveraging big data, AI, and machine learning. With tech-driven value-added services and efficient fulfilment facilities, Pickrr addresses the issues sellers in the D2C ecosystem face. [...] Among many things that the pandemic disrupted or transformed, logistics is one of those industries that saw demand pick up and also, and the need to transform came to the fore.

Domestic tech startups and SaaS companies are adopting AI-led innovations to provide novel add-ons to supply chain and logistics management solutions for enterprises across India. Here we have listed the top five AI startups (in no particular order) for logistics management in India.

### LogiNext

results.title: How tech startups are transforming logistics in digital India - ITLN
results.content:
LinkedLogi, a tech-first multimodal freight platform focused on streamlining logistics for businesses in India, has recently launched an AI-powered logistics solution. The platform enables Indian exporters to reduce turnaround times by up to 36%. LinkedLogi’s system integrates intelligent freight rate discovery, bidding, documentation, tracking, and payments into a single digital interface.

“LinkedLogi was created to bridge that gap. We’re not just offering a freight tool; we’re building confidence for exporters by giving them transparency, speed, and better margins through intelligent logistics management,” says Raj Somani, CEO and Founder, LinkedLogi. [...] Conclusion: Building the future of Indian logisticsIndia's logistics tech startups are not merely digitising existing processes; they are fundamentally reimagining how supply chains operate. From ONDC-enabled platforms that democratise commerce logistics to AI-powered enterprise solutions that optimise complex manufacturing networks, these startups are creating the infrastructure for India's digital economy.

With supportive government policies, increasing digital adoption, and a growing focus on sustainability, these startups are well-positioned to lead the next wave of supply chain transformation, not just in India but globally.

LogisticstechnologystartupsDivya CHShipfastKetan KulkarniGati Express and Supply ChainNitish RaiFreightFox

### Parijat Sourabh [...] AI and data: The intelligence layerArtificial intelligence is emerging as the differentiating factor for logistics tech startups. FreightFox's approach to AI implementation illustrates the practical applications of intelligent systems in supply chain management. “AI in India’s logistics space is still at a foundational stage. At FreightFox, we’re actively building the critical data infrastructure required to enable real-time, interoperable decision-making systems. A big part of our work is focused on creating structured, clean data sets that can be seamlessly exchanged across platforms and supply chain partners,” says Rai.

results.title: Amazon's Role in Shaping India's AI-Driven Logistics
results.content:
Since 2013, Amazon has supported India's entrepreneurial community, seeing it grow from 100 sellers to 1.7 million. With this growth in sellers, a growth in logistics capabilities has also occurred, with both expansions helping each other. The growth in sellers has meant a demand for better logistics capabilities, but the increase in logistics capabilities and fulfilment centres has allowed Indian sellers to grow loyal networks and meet consumer demand.

Amit adds:  “Looking ahead, we're excited to continue being a catalyst for India’s growth, as we democratise access to AI for millions of Indians and quadruple cumulative ecommerce exports enabled to US$80 billion by 2030."

## Indian logistics [...] With ongoing investments into India's infrastructure - such as the one by Amazon - the country's logistics capabilities and market is set to grow significantly. It is becoming a competitor within the global logistics market, with experts predicting continuous growth. The increasing digitalisation and job expansion, operational efficiency is increasing, networks are growing and India is establishing itself as a logistics competitor.

## Company portals

 ### Amazon
 ### DHL
 ### EY

## Executives

 ### Amit Agarwal

  SVP Emerging Markets

 Armanino Q&A: AI is Reshaping Manufacturing Supply Chains
 Boston Dynamics: Automating Supply Chains with AI Robots [...] “We have invested at scale in growing the physical and digital infrastructure for small businesses in India, creating millions of jobs, and taking Made-in-India global.”

## Network expansion

Through the ongoing investments by 2030, Amazon will be accelerating digital transformation, supporting country-wide innovation and strengthening infrastructure. The investment strategies align with India's own national priorities to expand AI capabilities, support small business growth, create jobs and upgrade logistics infrastructure.

In 2030, 3.8 million direct, indirect, induced and seasonal jobs will be supported by Amazon, in part due to its growing fulfilment and delivery network. This growing logistics network will support jobs within packaging, manufacturing and transportation.
